ThingDef.label: ash blindfish
ThingDef.description: As its name suggest, the ash blindfish completely lacks functioning eyes. Most people mistake these for diseased fish, and just throw them back in the water.

ThingDef.label: cutthroat trout
ThingDef.description: A species of trout that is usually found in clear waters, which leads many to assume it was introduced to the waterways of ashland regions.

ThingDef.label: foyada hopper
ThingDef.description: A primitive lobe-finned fish, only found in volcanic rashland regions. While they are usually found in lakes and sulphur pools, they can sometimes be found hopping around on land.\n\nSome local tribes have tales of giant foyoda hoppers, that swim in pools of lava. Of course no one has actually caught a foyoda hopper of such grandiose size.

ThingDef.label: gourami
ThingDef.description: Small, and rather colourful, fish that are often kept as pets. This particular species has adapted to life in ashland regions, and has been able to thrive in the nutrient rich ponds found there.

ThingDef.label: hoaga oto
ThingDef.description: A species of Loricariidae that can often be found in stagnant ponds in ashland regions.

ThingDef.label: ide
ThingDef.description: Often found in rivers and lakes in ashland regions. Develops a beautiful golden shine as it ages, though ide in ashland regions don't usually live long enough for that.

ThingDef.label: magma salmon
ThingDef.description: A species of salmon often found in ashland regions. Named after its vibrant red colouration, not because it lives in magma.

ThingDef.label: marsh angler
ThingDef.description: A large, mostly-aquatic, angler fish, usually found lurking in the murky waters of ashland regions. Care needs to be taken when handling marsh angler, as they have rows of retractable spines along their back, and a large maw filled with razor sharp teeth.\n\nThere are legends of enormous marsh angler big enough to swallow a kagouti whole. And a few even claim to have encountered marsh angler deep at sea large enough to predate whales.

ThingDef.label: mouthbrooder
ThingDef.description: A member of Osteoglossinae native to ashland regions. The mouthbrooder is named after how it carries its eggs and young in its mouth, a behaviour called mouthbrooding. This helps keep the vulnerable spawn safe from slaughterfish.

ThingDef.label: netch-hook eel
ThingDef.description: A species of freshwater eel native to ashland regions. Named after their long barbels, which are capable of releasing frightfully heart-stopping shocks. Some individuals are believed to be over 100 years old, and are certainly of a size that matches their age.

ThingDef.label: pilgrim goby
ThingDef.description: A species of goby common in ashland regions, named after being found almost anywhere there is water.

ThingDef.label: old man gar
ThingDef.description: A rare species of gar, rarely found in fresh waters in ashland regions.

ThingDef.label: rainbow zander
ThingDef.description: A small species of fish, rarely found in the fresh waters in ashland regions. While its multi-coloured scales are rather beautiful, they make the rainbow zander a prime target for slaughterfish.

ThingDef.label: ricefish
ThingDef.description: A small species of fish that can often be found hiding between saltrice stems.

ThingDef.label: shalk-brother crayfish
ThingDef.description: A brilliant blue species of crayfish, often found in the fresh waters of ashland regions. A rather rare sight due to slaughterfish infestations.

ThingDef.label: siltfish
ThingDef.description: A lobe-finned fish that can often found in the shallow silty waters of ashland regions.

ThingDef.label: scum carp
ThingDef.description: A species of carp that can often be found in ashland regions experiencing extreme volcanic activity. It has quite an odd taste, and doesn't exactly smell great when cooked.

ThingDef.label: tench
ThingDef.description: A fairly common sight in stagnant pools of water in ashland regions, tench are able to grow quite large thanks to the abundance of prey found in these waters.

ThingDef.label: thorny catfish
ThingDef.description: A small species of catfish that can often be found in stagnant ponds in ashland regions.

ThingDef.label: toadstool tilapia
ThingDef.description: A species of tilapia native to the fresh waters of ashland regions. Named after its striking red colouration, which many associate with that of a toadstool.
